title: How to Make Chili Sauce

steps.headline: Put all of the ingredients into a saucepan.
steps.description:
Place a saucepan on the stove and pour in 1 cup (225 g) of tomato sauce along with 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of vinegar and 2 tablespoons (29.6 ml) (30 g) of tomato paste. Add 2 tablespoons (29.6 ml) (25 g) of brown sugar and stir in:
1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of chili powder
1/8 teaspoon (0.3 g) of ground cinnamon
5 to 6 dashes of Tabasco to taste
1 dash of cloves
1 dash of allspice

steps.headline: Turn the burner to medium and bring the sauce to a simmer.
steps.description: Keep the lid off of the saucepan as you heat the chili sauce. Stir it occasionally until it begins to bubble a little. Heating the sauce intensifies the flavors. If you're short on time, you can simply mix all of the ingredients and begin using the sauce, but it will lack the same flavor.

steps.headline: Simmer the uncovered sauce for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Adjust the burner if the sauce begins to boil vigorously. Continue to stir the sauce every few minutes to prevent it from sticking to the bottom of the pan.

steps.headline: Cool the sauce to room temperature.
steps.description: Turn off the burner and let the chili sauce come to room temperature before you use or store it. To store the sauce, transfer it to an airtight container and refrigerate it for up to 2 weeks.<Tip: The sauce will become more flavorful as it's stored, so try to make it a day before you plan on using it. Try using the chili sauce in place of ketchup on a burger or hotdog.

steps.headline: Put the chiles, garlic, and half of the rice wine vinegar in a food processor.
steps.description: Trim the stems off of 1½ cups (135 g) of fresh Thai chiles and put the chiles in the bowl of a food processor. Add 2 or 3 peeled garlic cloves and 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of rice wine vinegar.Tip: If you can't find fresh chiles, use 15 dried chili peppers. Soak the dried chiles in boiling water for 30 minutes before draining them.

steps.headline: Blend the mixture until it's as smooth as you like.
steps.description: Put the lid on the food processor and pulse the chiles until they're combined with the garlic. Then, process the mixture until it's as smooth and saucy as you want. If you want to thin out the sauce even more, add the remaining 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of rice wine vinegar and blend until it's incorporated.

steps.headline: Blend in the salt and optional brown sugar and fish sauce.
steps.description: Add 1 teaspoon (5.5 g) of salt to the chili sauce. If you'd like slightly sweet sauce, add 1 tablespoon (14.8 ml) (12 g) of brown sugar. For a greater depth of flavor add 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of fish sauce. Then, pulse the sauce to incorporate the seasoning. If you're trying to replicate the flavors of sriracha sauce, use the brown sugar but leave out the fish sauce. If you'd like the flavor of sambal oelek, cut back on the sugar and add another splash of vinegar.

steps.headline: Refrigerate the sauce in an airtight container for up to 1 month.
steps.description: Put the garlic chili sauce in a small jar or bottle and screw on a lid. Label the jar and include the date. Plan on using it within 1 month or store the sauce in the freezer for up to 6 months. To defrost the chili sauce, place the bottle or jar in the fridge for 1 or 2 days before using it.

steps.headline: Put water, vinegar, sugar, garlic, soy sauce, and chili flakes in a pan.
steps.description: Pour ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of the water into a saucepan along with ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of rice vinegar. Add 1 cup (200 g) of sugar, 6 minced garlic cloves, 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of soy sauce, and 4 to 6 teaspoons (9 to 14 g) of red chili flakes. If you'd also like a greater depth of flavor, add 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of fish sauce.Tip: You can also use 3 fresh Thai birds eye chiles with their seeds or a 3 Thai sweet chiles. Chop the chiles finely and include the seeds.

steps.headline: Boil the mixture for 3 minutes and stir it occasionally.
steps.description: Turn the burner to medium-high and stir to combine the ingredients in the pan. Heat the mixture until it begins to boil steadily. Stir the mixture frequently to prevent it from sticking to the pan.

steps.headline: Whisk the cornstarch and 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of water in a small bowl.
steps.description: Pour the water into a small bowl and add 1 tablespoon (9 g) of cornstarch. Use a small whisk or spoon to combine the mixture so it forms a smooth slurry. The cornstarch slurry will thicken the sweet chili sauce.

steps.headline: Turn the burner to low and whisk in the cornstarch slurry.
steps.description: Whisk the sauce with 1 hand while you slowly pour in the cornstarch slurry. Although it's white, the mixture will become clear as it cooks. Don't dump the cornstarch slurry in at once or it may become lumpy in the sauce.

steps.headline: Whisk the sauce constantly for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Adjust the burner so it bubbles very gently and continue to whisk. Turn off the burner once the sweet chili sauce is as thick as you like. The sauce will continue to thicken as it cools down.

steps.headline: Turn off the burner and cool the sauce to room temperature.
steps.description: Once it's cooled down, transfer the sweet chili sauce to a clean bottle or jar. Store the sauce in the refrigerator for up to 1 month. Avoid freezing this sauce since it doesn't defrost well.

text:
Making Tomato-Based Chili Sauce Put all of the ingredients into a saucepan. Place a saucepan on the stove and pour in 1 cup (225 g) of tomato sauce along with 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of vinegar and 2 tablespoons (29.6 ml) (30 g) of tomato paste. Add 2 tablespoons (29.6 ml) (25 g) of brown sugar and stir in:
1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of chili powder
1/8 teaspoon (0.3 g) of ground cinnamon
5 to 6 dashes of Tabasco to taste
1 dash of cloves
1 dash of allspice Turn the burner to medium and bring the sauce to a simmer. Keep the lid off of the saucepan as you heat the chili sauce. Stir it occasionally until it begins to bubble a little. Heating the sauce intensifies the flavors. If you're short on time, you can simply mix all of the ingredients and begin using the sauce, but it will lack the same flavor. Simmer the uncovered sauce for 20 minutes. Adjust the burner if the sauce begins to boil vigorously. Continue to stir the sauce every few minutes to prevent it from sticking to the bottom of the pan. Cool the sauce to room temperature. Turn off the burner and let the chili sauce come to room temperature before you use or store it. To store the sauce, transfer it to an airtight container and refrigerate it for up to 2 weeks.<Tip: The sauce will become more flavorful as it's stored, so try to make it a day before you plan on using it. Try using the chili sauce in place of ketchup on a burger or hotdog. Blending Spicy Garlic Chili Sauce Put the chiles, garlic, and half of the rice wine vinegar in a food processor. Trim the stems off of 1½ cups (135 g) of fresh Thai chiles and put the chiles in the bowl of a food processor. Add 2 or 3 peeled garlic cloves and 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of rice wine vinegar.Tip: If you can't find fresh chiles, use 15 dried chili peppers. Soak the dried chiles in boiling water for 30 minutes before draining them. Blend the mixture until it's as smooth as you like. Put the lid on the food processor and pulse the chiles until they're combined with the garlic. Then, process the mixture until it's as smooth and saucy as you want. If you want to thin out the sauce even more, add the remaining 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of rice wine vinegar and blend until it's incorporated. Blend in the salt and optional brown sugar and fish sauce. Add 1 teaspoon (5.5 g) of salt to the chili sauce. If you'd like slightly sweet sauce, add 1 tablespoon (14.8 ml) (12 g) of brown sugar. For a greater depth of flavor add 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of fish sauce. Then, pulse the sauce to incorporate the seasoning. If you're trying to replicate the flavors of sriracha sauce, use the brown sugar but leave out the fish sauce. If you'd like the flavor of sambal oelek, cut back on the sugar and add another splash of vinegar. Refrigerate the sauce in an airtight container for up to 1 month. Put the garlic chili sauce in a small jar or bottle and screw on a lid. Label the jar and include the date. Plan on using it within 1 month or store the sauce in the freezer for up to 6 months. To defrost the chili sauce, place the bottle or jar in the fridge for 1 or 2 days before using it. Mixing Sweet Chili Sauce Put water, vinegar, sugar, garlic, soy sauce, and chili flakes in a pan. Pour ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of the water into a saucepan along with ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of rice vinegar. Add 1 cup (200 g) of sugar, 6 minced garlic cloves, 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of soy sauce, and 4 to 6 teaspoons (9 to 14 g) of red chili flakes. If you'd also like a greater depth of flavor, add 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of fish sauce.Tip: You can also use 3 fresh Thai birds eye chiles with their seeds or a 3 Thai sweet chiles. Chop the chiles finely and include the seeds. Boil the mixture for 3 minutes and stir it occasionally. Turn the burner to medium-high and stir to combine the ingredients in the pan. Heat the mixture until it begins to boil steadily. Stir the mixture frequently to prevent it from sticking to the pan. Whisk the cornstarch and 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of water in a small bowl. Pour the water into a small bowl and add 1 tablespoon (9 g) of cornstarch. Use a small whisk or spoon to combine the mixture so it forms a smooth slurry. The cornstarch slurry will thicken the sweet chili sauce. Turn the burner to low and whisk in the cornstarch slurry. Whisk the sauce with 1 hand while you slowly pour in the cornstarch slurry. Although it's white, the mixture will become clear as it cooks. Don't dump the cornstarch slurry in at once or it may become lumpy in the sauce. Whisk the sauce constantly for 5 minutes. Adjust the burner so it bubbles very gently and continue to whisk. Turn off the burner once the sweet chili sauce is as thick as you like. The sauce will continue to thicken as it cools down. Turn off the burner and cool the sauce to room temperature. Once it's cooled down, transfer the sweet chili sauce to a clean bottle or jar. Store the sauce in the refrigerator for up to 1 month. Avoid freezing this sauce since it doesn't defrost well.
